intro: Gomphia subcordata, commonly known as the narrow-lobed gomphia, is a unique member of the Restionaceae family, native to South Africa. It is characterized by its erect, grass-like appearance with narrow, linear leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. The plant produces small, clustered inflorescences bearing tiny, white to pale yellow flowers. It typically grows in coastal areas and sandy soils, adapting well to saline and arid conditions. Due to its specific habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and threatened species.
